comment:
Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management for Large Banks Introduction The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) has identified the effects of climate change and the transition to a low carbon economy as presenting emerging risks to banks1 and the financial system.2 Banks are likely to be affected by both the physical risks and transition risks associated with climate change (referred to in these draft principles as climate-related financial risks). Physical risks refer to the harm to people and property arising from acute, climate-related events, such as hurricanes, wildfires, floods, and heatwaves, and chronic shifts in climate, including higher average temperatures, changes in precipitation patterns, sea level rise, and ocean acidification. Transition risks refer to stresses to certain banks or sectors arising from the shifts in policy, consumer and business sentiment, or technologies associated with the changes necessary to limit climate change. Weaknesses in how banks identify, measure, monitor, and control the potential physical and transition risks associated with a changing climate could adversely affect a bank’s safety and soundness, as well as the overall financial system. Adverse effects could include potentially disproportionate impact on the financially vulnerable, including low- to moderate-income (LMI) and other disadvantaged households and communities.3 Many banks are considering these risks and would benefit from additional guidance as they develop capabilities, deploy resources, and make necessary investments to address climate-related financial risks. These draft principles provide a high-level framework for the safe and sound management of exposures to climate-related financial risks, consistent with the existing risk management framework described in existing OCC rules and guidance. The principles are intended to support efforts by banks to focus on key aspects of climate risk management. The principles will help bank management make progress toward answering key questions on exposures and incorporating climate-related financial risks into banks’ risk management frameworks. Although all banks, regardless of size, may have material exposures to climate-related financial risks, these draft principles are targeted at the largest banks, those with over $100 billion in total 1 In this issuance, the term “bank” refers collectively to national banks, Federal savings associations, and Federal branches or agencies of foreign banking organizations. 2 See e.g. Semiannual Risk Perspective at pp. 2-4 (Fall 2021), available at https://www.occ.treas.gov/publications- and-resources/publications/semiannual-risk-perspective/files/pub-semiannual-risk-perspective-fall-2021.pdf. For additional background, see generally Report on Climate-Related Financial Risk, Financial Stability Oversight Council (Oct. 21, 2021) (FSOC Climate Report). 3 For further information, see Staff Reports, Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Understanding the Linkages between Climate Change and Inequality in the United States, No. 991 (November 2021), available at https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/staff_reports/sr991.html.
consolidated assets. The OCC is inviting public feedback on the principles for 60 days, until February 14, 2022. The OCC plans to elaborate on these principles in subsequent guidance that would distinguish roles and responsibilities of boards of directors (boards) and management, incorporate the feedback received on the principles, and consider lessons learned and best practices from the industry and other jurisdictions. In keeping with the OCC’s risk-based approach to supervision, the OCC intends to appropriately tailor any resulting supervisory expectations to reflect differences in banks’ circumstances such as complexity of operations and business models. General Principles Governance. An effective risk governance framework is essential to a bank’s safe and sound operation. A bank’s board and management should demonstrate an appropriate understanding of climate-related financial risk exposures and their impact on risk appetite to facilitate oversight. Sound governance includes reviewing information necessary to oversee the bank, allocating appropriate resources, assigning climate-related financial risk responsibilities throughout the organization (i.e., committees, reporting lines, and roles), and clearly communicating to staff regarding climate-related impacts to the bank’s risk profile. Responsibility and accountability may be integrated within existing organizational structures or by establishing new structures for climate-related financial risks. Where dedicated units are established, the board and management should clearly define these units’ responsibilities and interaction with existing governance structures. The board should have adequate understanding and knowledge to assess the potential impact of climate-related risks on the bank and to address and oversee these risks within the bank’s strategy and risk appetite, including an understanding of the potential ways in which these risks could evolve over various time horizons and scenarios. Relevant time horizons may include those that extend beyond the bank’s typical strategic planning horizon. The board should actively oversee the bank’s risk-taking activities and hold management accountable for adhering to the risk governance framework. Management is responsible for executing the bank’s overall strategic plan. This responsibility includes effectively managing all risks, including climate- related financial risks, and their effects on the bank’s financial condition. Management should also hold staff accountable for controlling risks within established lines of authority and responsibility. Additionally, management is responsible for regularly reporting to the board on the level and nature of risks to the bank, including climate-related financial risks. Policies, Procedures, and Limits. Management should incorporate climate-related risks into policies, procedures, and limits to provide detailed guidance on the bank’s approach to these risks in line with the strategy and risk appetite set by the board. Policies, procedures, and limits should be modified when necessary to reflect the distinctive characteristics of climate-related risks and changes to the bank’s activities. Strategic Planning. The board and management should consider material climate-related financial risk exposures when setting the bank’s overall business strategy, risk appetite, and financial, capital, and operational plans. As part of forward-looking strategic planning, the board and management should address the potential impact of climate-related financial risk exposures on the bank’s financial condition, operations (including geographic locations), and business 2
objectives over various time horizons. The board and management should also consider climate- related financial risk impacts on stakeholders’ expectations, the bank’s reputation, and LMI and other disadvantaged households and communities, including physical harm or access to bank products and services. The OCC recognizes that the incorporation of material climate-related financial risks into various planning processes is iterative as measurement methodologies, models, and data for analyzing these risks continue to evolve and mature over time. Any climate-related strategies, including any relevant corporate social responsibility objectives, should align with and support the bank’s broader strategy, risk appetite, and risk management framework. In addition, where banks engage in public communication of their climate-related strategies, boards and management should ensure that any public statements about their banks’ climate-related strategies and commitments are consistent with their internal strategies and risk appetite statements. Risk Management. Climate-related financial risks typically impact banks through a range of traditional risk types. Management should oversee the development and implementation of processes to identify, measure, monitor, and control climate-related financial risk exposures within the bank’s existing risk management framework. A bank should employ a comprehensive process to identify emerging and material risks stemming from the bank’s business activities and associated exposures. The risk identification process should include input from stakeholders across the organization with relevant expertise (e.g., business units, independent risk management, and legal). Risk identification includes assessment of climate-related financial risks across a range of plausible scenarios and under various time horizons. As part of sound risk management, banks should develop processes to measure and monitor material climate-related financial risks and to inform management about the materiality of those risks. Material climate-related financial risk exposures should be clearly defined, aligned with the bank’s risk appetite, and supported by appropriate metrics (e.g., risk limits and key risk indicators) and escalation processes. Boards and management should also incorporate climate- related risks into their internal control frameworks, including internal audit. Tools and approaches for measuring and monitoring exposure to climate-related risks include, among others, exposure analysis, heat maps, climate risk dashboards, and scenario analysis. These tools can be leveraged to assess a bank’s exposure to both physical and transition risks in both the shorter and longer term. Outputs should inform the risk identification process and the short- and long-term financial risks to a bank’s business model from climate change. Data, Risk Measurement, and Reporting. Sound climate risk management depends on the availability of relevant, accurate, and timely data. Management should incorporate climate- related financial risk information into the bank’s internal reporting, monitoring, and escalation processes to facilitate timely and sound decision-making across the bank. Effective risk data aggregation and reporting capabilities allow management to capture and report material and emerging climate-related financial risk exposures, segmented or stratified by physical and transition risks, based upon the complexity and types of exposures. Data, risk measurement, modeling methodologies, and reporting continue to evolve at a rapid pace; management should monitor these developments and incorporate them into their climate risk management as warranted. 3
Scenario Analysis. Climate-related scenario analysis is emerging as an important approach for identifying, measuring, and managing climate-related risks. For the purposes of this guidance, climate-related scenario analysis refers to exercises used to conduct a forward-looking assessment of the potential impact on a bank of changes in the economy, financial system, or the distribution of physical hazards resulting from climate-related risks. These exercises differ from traditional stress testing exercises that typically assess the potential impacts of transitory shocks to near-term economic and financial conditions. An effective climate-related scenario analysis framework provides a comprehensive and forward-looking perspective that banks can apply alongside existing risk management practices to evaluate the resiliency of a bank’s strategy and risk management to the structural changes arising from climate-related risks. Management should develop and implement climate-related scenario analysis frameworks in a manner commensurate to the bank’s size, complexity, business activity, and risk profile. These frameworks should include clearly defined objectives that reflect the bank’s overall climate risk management strategies. These objectives could include, for example, exploring the impacts of climate-related risks on the bank’s strategy and business model, identifying and measuring vulnerability to relevant climate-related risk factors including physical and transition risks, and estimating climate-related exposures and potential losses across a range of plausible scenarios. In the near term, a climate-related scenario analysis framework can also assist the bank in identifying data and methodological limitations and uncertainty in climate risk management and informing the adequacy of its climate risk management framework. Climate-related scenario analyses should be subject to oversight, validation, and quality control standards that would be commensurate to their risk. Climate-related scenario analysis results should be clearly and regularly communicated to all relevant individuals within the bank, including an appropriate level of information necessary to effectively convey the assumptions, limitations, and uncertainty of results. Management of Risk Areas A risk assessment process is part of a sound risk governance framework, and it allows boards and management to identify emerging risks and to develop and implement appropriate strategies to mitigate those risks. Boards and management should consider and incorporate climate-related financial risks when identifying and mitigating all types of risk. These risk assessment principles describe how climate-related financial risks can be addressed in various risk categories. The OCC will elaborate on these risk assessment principles in subsequent guidance. Credit Risk. The board and management should consider climate-related financial risks as part of the underwriting and ongoing monitoring of portfolios. Effective credit risk management practices could include monitoring climate-related credit risks through sectoral, geographic, and single-name concentration analyses, including credit risk concentrations stemming from physical and transition risks. As part of concentration risk analysis, management should assess potential changes in correlations across exposures or asset classes. The board and management should determine credit risk appetite and lending limits related to these risks. 4
Liquidity Risk. Consistent with sound oversight and liquidity risk management, the board and management should assess whether climate-related financial risks could affect liquidity buffers and, if so, incorporate those risks into their liquidity risk management and liquidity buffers. Other Financial Risk. Management should monitor interest rate risk and other model inputs for greater volatility or less predictability due to climate-related financial risks. Where appropriate, management should include corresponding measures of conservatism in their risk measurements and controls. The board and management should monitor how climate-related financial risks affect the bank’s exposure to risk related to changing prices. While market participants are still researching how to measure climate price risk, the board and management should use the best measurement methodologies reasonably available to them and refine them over time. Operational Risk. The board and management should consider how climate-related financial risk exposures may adversely impact a bank’s operations, control environment, and operational resilience. Sound operational risk management includes incorporating an assessment across all business lines and operations, including third-party operations, and considering climate-related impacts on business continuity and the evolving legal and regulatory landscape. Legal/Compliance Risk. The board and management should consider how climate-related financial risks and risk mitigation measures affect the legal and regulatory landscape in which the bank operates. This consideration includes possible changes to legal requirements for, or underwriting considerations related to, flood or disaster-related insurance. It also includes possible fair lending concerns if the bank’s risk mitigation measures disproportionately affect communities or households on a prohibited basis such as race or ethnicity. Other Nonfinancial Risk. Consistent with sound oversight, the board and management should monitor how the execution of strategic decisions and the operating environment affect the bank’s financial condition and operational resilience as discussed in the strategic planning section. The board and management should also consider the extent to which the bank’s activities may increase the risk of negative financial impact from reputational damage, liability, or litigation, and implement adequate measures to account for these risks where material. Request for Feedback The OCC welcomes feedback on all aspects of these draft principles, including on the following questions. Among other uses, the OCC would consider responses in connection with developing any future guidance on climate-related financial risks. Refer to OCC Bulletin 2021-62 for instructions on submitting feedback. Applicability 1. Are there additional categories of banks (i.e., based on asset size, location, business model) to which these principles should apply? 5
Tailoring 2. How could future guidance assist a bank in developing its climate-related financial risk management practices commensurate to its size, complexity, risk profile, and scope of operations? General 3. What challenges do banks face in incorporating these principles into their risk management systems? How should the OCC further engage with banks to understand those challenges? Current Risk Management Practices 4. What specific tools or strategies have banks used to successfully incorporate climate-related financial risks into their risk management frameworks? 5. How do banks determine when climate-related financial risks are material and warrant greater than routine attention by the board and management? 6. What time horizon do banks consider relevant when identifying and assessing the materiality of climate-related financial risks? 7. What, if any, specific products, practices, and strategies–for example, insurance or derivatives contracts or other capital market instruments–do banks use to hedge, transfer, or mitigate climate-related financial risks? 8. What, if any, climate-related financial products or services–for example, “green bonds,” derivatives, dedicated investment funds, or other instruments that take climate-related considerations into account–do banks offer to clients and customers?4 What risks, if any, do these products or services pose? 9. How do banks currently consider the impacts of climate-related financial risk mitigation strategies and financial products on households and communities, specifically LMI and other disadvantaged communities? Data, Disclosures, and Reporting 10. What, if any, specific climate-related data, metrics, tools, and models from borrowers and other counterparties do banks need to identify, measure, monitor, and control their own climate-related financial risks? How do banks currently obtain this information? What gaps and other concerns are there with respect to these data, metrics, tools, or models? 11. How could existing regulatory reporting requirements be augmented to better capture banks’ exposure to climate-related financial risks? 4 “Green bonds” refer to fixed-income securities, the proceeds of which are earmarked for environmentally beneficial investment. 6
Scenario Analysis 12. Scenario analysis is an important component of climate risk management that requires assumptions about plausible future states of the world. How do banks use climate scenario models, analysis, or tools and what challenges do they face? 13. What factors are most salient for the OCC to consider when designing and executing scenario analysis exercises? 7
summary: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) has proposed draft principles for managing climate-related financial risks in large banks, emphasizing the need for effective governance, strategic planning, and risk management. These principles address both physical risks (e.g., hurricanes, floods) and transition risks (e.g., policy shifts) associated with climate change. The OCC highlights the importance of integrating climate risks into banks' existing risk management frameworks, including governance, policies, strategic planning, and scenario analysis. The draft principles are targeted at banks with over $100 billion in assets, aiming to support their efforts in managing climate risks. The OCC seeks public feedback on these principles to refine future guidance, considering banks' size, complexity, and risk profiles. The proposal also addresses the potential disproportionate impact on financially vulnerable communities and emphasizes the need for banks to consider climate risks in credit, liquidity, operational, and legal risk management. The OCC invites feedback on various aspects, including applicability, challenges, tools, and data needs, to enhance banks' climate risk management practices.

February 14, 2022 Michael J. Hsu, Acting Comptroller of the Currency Office of the Comptroller of the Currency 400 7th St. SW, Suite 3E-218 Washington, D.C. 20219 Via File Upload to https://regulations.gov/ Re: Docket ID OCC-2021-0023 – Public consultation on Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management for Large Banks Dear Comptroller Hsu, Thank you for soliciting feedback on the Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management for Large Banks. Please accept these comments on behalf of Atmos Financial, PBC (“Atmos”). Atmos is a financial technology banking services provider, founded in 2020 with the express purpose of using the power of banking to address the climate crisis. We engage with the banking sector in multiple ways. Specifically, we aggregate deposits from consumers interested in growing a low-carbon economy, and facilitate banks to engage in scalable, low-interest climate-positive loan programs. As a party to lending arrangements with banks subject to OCC regulation, we benefit from regulations that factor climate risk into their risk management practices. We would first like to thank the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) for designing these Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management for Large Banks. We also congratulate the OCC for sharing “Five Climate Questions Every Bank Board Should Ask.” We agree with the OCC that addressing weaknesses in how banks identify, measure, monitor, and control potential climate-related financial risks is critical to ensuring the safety and soundness of U.S. banks and the global financial system. Below please find our comments in response to some of your specific questions related to the proposed principles. Page 1 of 14
Applicability 1. Are there additional categories of banks (i.e., based on asset size, location, business model) to which these principles should apply? We agree with the OCC that all banks, regardless of size, may have material exposures to climate-related financial risks. While we understand that the OCC has designed these proposed principles to initially target banks with over $100 billion in total consolidated assets (i.e., the largest banks), we believe that the existential threat posed by climate change necessitates extending the application of these principles to all US Banks, irrespective of asset size, location, or business model. Climate change risk permeates all aspects of the capital markets, posing grave threats to all banks with increasing frequency and severity. According to NOAA, in 2021 there were 20 separate weather and climate disaster events where losses per event exceeded $1 billion: 688 people lost their lives due to climate-related disasters, and the total financial cost in the United States was more than $145 billion. More importantly, we know these losses will only continue to increase until and unless meaningful action is taken to dramatically reduce emissions in line with science-based targets. These acute and progressive physical risks have the potential to seriously disrupt the stability of the banking system and the communities they serve. For example, in 2021 more than 40 percent of Americans live in counties hit by climate disasters and more than 80 percent of Americans experienced a heat wave. Climate impacts are already manifesting in the largest state economies. In just the last few years, our home state of California has experienced record-breaking wildfires, in both number and size, that have taken hundreds of lives, bankrupted our largest utility, left millions regularly without power and brought home insurability into question. Given the lack of significant change in economic systems to materially reduce emissions, these physical risks are certain to increase in frequency and severity in the years to come. We are increasingly concerned that banks that engage in mortgage lending in disaster prone areas may not be sufficiently monitoring the increased likelihood of mortgage defaults after climate disasters. For example, mortgages in Hurricane Harvey FEMA designated counties saw a significant increase in 90+ day delinquency when compared to delinquency rates just six months prior. Within FEMA designated counties, properties estimated to have damage saw a 205% increase in 90+ day delinquency, while properties estimated to have no damage saw a Page 2 of 14
167% increase in 90+ day delinquency.1 In a worst case scenario multiple disasters occurring nearly simultaneously across different parts of the country can create billions of dollars of damages and cumulative losses. This scenario occured in 2018 where 15 named Hurricanes hit the United States causing over $50 billion in damages in the same 6 month period that the Camp Fire in California that caused over $16 billion in losses. Already, insurance is not a guaranteed mitigator for the costs of these risks. As insurance companies begin to pull coverage from areas that face higher risk of wildfires, an increasing number of homes are likely to be designated as uninsurable. Where the science is unmistakable about the likelihood of the increased frequency and intensity of weather events, and it is foreseeable that billions of dollars property stand in harm's way, cascading mortgage delinquencies and potentially defaults could destabilize certain financial institutions without appropriate risk management strategies. Furthermore, the foreseeable risks to property will require clear language for climate related underwriting, collateral and risk standards while ensuring compliance with fair lending laws. In short, climate risk is an existential threat which poses an emerging and increasing threat to U.S. financial stability. Climate risk potentially poses the greatest threat to smaller banks located in higher-risk communities, compared to large banks and smaller banks in climate-resilient geographies. Nevertheless, because climate impact is not geographically contained, and is instead a phenomenon that is caused by and impacts each of us in various parts of the global supply chain, it is appropriate that regulatory guidance be applied across the entire industry. We therefore urge the OCC to extend its Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management to all US banks. We also encourage the OCC to make some or all of these principles prescriptive, rather than voluntary best practices. Using its authority under 12 U.S.C. § 1831p-1, we believe OCC can finalize this guidance and enforce it as a mandatory requirement, while creating size- and risk-based milestones that appease those opposed to such regulation. After these guidelines are finalized, the OCC should continue to create even more in-depth requirements. The European Central Bank, the Bank of England, and other foreign financial regulatory agencies are already taking similar steps, and we encourage you to make use of the 1See Kousky, Palim & Pan,(2020) ”Flood Damage and Mortgage Credit Risk: A Case Study of Hurrican Harvey,” Journal of Housing Research, 29:sup1, S86-S120, DOI:10.1080/10527001.2020.1840131Also see Amy Gromwoski,“The Impact of Natural Disaster on Mortgage Delinquency,”CoreLogic, September 2018, available at https://www.corelogic.com/intelligence/the-impact-of-natural-catastrophe-on-mortgage-delinquency/; Page 3 of 14
data they are collecting in this process. We also encourage you, wherever possible, to conform US principles and guidance to meet international goals and standards. Acknowledging the cost and burden such guidelines may have on smaller banks, we suggest the OCC implement a staggered timeline to provide smaller banks ample time to incorporate an applicable implementation strategy. A timeline could be determined based on size- and risk-based milestones derived by the OCC. Providing such broad guidance now with ample implementation time will result in the emergence of qualified vendors to ease the capital and knowledge burden for smaller banks to meet these principles. Tailoring 2. How could future guidance assist a bank in developing its climate-related financial risk management practices commensurate to its size, complexity, risk profile, and scope of operations? We suggest detailed guidance be provided for all banks to perform a preliminary self-assessment of their own exposure to climate-related financial risk and submit that assessment to the OCC for review. The OCC should provide detailed prescriptive guidance to expand existing risk criteria as a part of periodic self assessments that take into account geographic exposure, scope of operations, and time frames as developed in coordination with FSOC partners. Audit and assurance firms may be able to effectively aid banks in making these assessments though should not be relied upon. Providing simple, but detailed guidance about how banks should undertake climate related risk management modeling would be an important first step. Once banks report the results of these self assessments, the OCC can exercise its oversight authority by tailoring its climate related risk requirements to ensure that data and modeling approaches are uniform and provide the information needed to assess whether more explicit standards are needed. Results of each bank’s self-assessment, reviewable and requiring approval from the OCC, should dictate the timeline under which climate-related financial risk management practices need to be adopted for formal ongoing reporting. Banks with the lowest potential climate-related risk, which likely include smaller banks in less impacted geographies, would be granted the most amount of time to begin formally reporting based on OCC dictated climate-related financial risk management practices. The largest banks should be required to meet the earliest possible Page 4 of 14
deadline due to the systemic impact of their potential exposure and so that such learnings may be applied to smaller banks around the country. Banks will independently assess the increased risks associated with OCC guidance and incorporate such risks into their capital, loan pricing and credit allocation decisions going forward. As banks make such determinations independently, they may find it helpful to have options to unwind “stranded assets” as a result of the physical risks of the climate-related economic transition. As the OCC reviews such options, financial aid should be limited to legacy assets only. Limiting financial aid to assets constructed before a determined date will ensure banks don’t abuse such resources for their own financial gain at the expense of society and climate risk at large. Atmos also recommends that future guidance for banks and bank holding companies involved in the trading and marketing of non-renewable commodities (including physical energy commodities and physical energy commodity derivatives) include a requirement to disclose the impact of climate-related risk drivers (including operational risk) around these products and services. Appropriate disclosures will ensure stakeholders are sufficiently warned of value fluctuation of the bank or bank holding company based on exposure to such commodities. General 3. What challenges do banks face in incorporating these principles into their risk management systems? How should the OCC further engage with banks to understand those challenges? Many banks currently lack sufficient knowledge-capital to assess climate-related financial risks. Guidance by the OCC directing banks to perform self-assessments would need to be sufficient and simple enough to be made applicable to all banks. Enabling a tiered implementation timeline incorporating factors like bank size, risk-profile, geographic exposure, etc. will ensure that banks that wield the greatest influence over the safety and soundness of the US economy are carrying the greatest burden related to the adoption of such practices. Analogous to the relationship between Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and the International Accounting Standards Board, all efforts should be made to conform Principles for Page 5 of 14
Climate-Related Financial Risk Management to internationally driven guidance. Implementing two sets of similar but different guidance will increase the implementation burden and complexity of reporting for large banks in particular operating across regulatory jurisdictions. Below are listed various challenges banks are currently encountering. ● In some cases, banks are unsure of which climate scenarios are most relevant for their business model, or the most relevant scenarios do not provide sufficient detail in some areas critical to financial institutions. ● Climate models are continually being adjusted, while the associated risks to banks and bank holding companies are not updated continuously to incorporate the changing risks to their portfolio holdings. ● Banks’ internal risk departments have no immediate background in assessing climate risk and are not sufficiently informed to make risk-based calls without more prescriptive scientific background. ● Banks may have an imperfect understanding of the risks associated with non-asset based commercial loans, derived from imperfect information provided by portfolio companies. The anticipated plans for the Securities and Exchange Commission to propose climate disclosure for public companies should have a beneficial impact for all banks to gain more comprehensive and consistent information from their large clients. ● Banks may not be fully undertaking a geographic based assessment of their exposure to derivative instruments including mortgage back securities and collateralized debt obligations originated for areas of the country that are particularly vulnerable to the increased physical impacts of climate change, like wildfires, hurricanes and sea level rise, under climate risk scenario modeling. In addition to the technical challenges above, banks may face increasing challenges of managing the potential volatility in the costs of capital or liquidity as climate related financial risks manifest across sectors. Many of these challenges are market-driven and should be permitted to take effect to accelerate change across sectors more broadly but must be monitored and managed to ensure stability across financial institutions as the transition unfolds. The OCC should also make clear that having a transition plan is a crucial part of a bank’s risk management system, and provide guidance as to how these plans should be formed. Current Risk Management Practices Page 6 of 14
4. What specific tools or strategies have banks used to successfully incorporate climate-related financial risks into their risk management frameworks? N/A 5. How do banks determine when climate-related financial risks are material and warrant greater than routine attention by the board and management? It is our understanding that banks are just beginning to incorporate greater review by the board and/or management as it relates to climate-related financial risks. However, review is largely still qualitative and discussion-based while a quantified review of risk and materiality assessment has not been broadly adopted. However, much can be learned from the recent European Central Bank (ECB) economy-wide climate stress tests methodology and results. There the results revealed that climate risks are concentrated in certain regions and sectors. Furthermore, testing revealed that some 70% of loan exposures of euro area banks that are subject to future physical hazards are concentrated in the hands of only 25 banks.2 With a lack of guidance from regulatory bodies, relative to other prioritized issues, there may be a false perception that such risks are likely not near-term nor material enough to warrant an immediate review and policy change. Such perceptions may lead to imprudent financial risk taking that imperils the long-term stability of the financial sector in the absences of regulatory guidance. 6. What time horizon do banks consider relevant when identifying and assessing the materiality of climate-related financial risks? It is our understanding that banks generally are not considering climate-related financial risks with time horizons longer than five years. The short-term view of banks broadly is contrary to international goals for addressing the existential threats posed by the climate crisis. In 2020, Ceres produced a report highlighting the risk due to transition risks of the largest banks. In 2021, Ceres prepared an analysis of the physical risks of climate change to banks. Both of these reports highlight the imperative to have a longer time frame in the analysis. 2See European Central Bank, Climate-related risk and financial stability, Project team on Risk Monitoring, July 2021 available at https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/pdf/other/ecb.climateriskfinancialstability202107~87822fae81.en.pdf. Page 7 of 14
Climate-related risks should be incorporated over a period of 30 or more years to sufficiently take into account the real risks facing the economy. 7. What, if any, specific products, practices, and strategies–for example, insurance or derivatives contracts or other capital market instruments–do banks use to hedge, transfer, or mitigate climate-related financial risks? Based on our interactions, many of the largest banks have used, or have considered using, both insurance and carbon offsets to mitigate climate-related financial risks. Regarding the use of insurance contracts, we believe that the residential and commercial mortgage divisions of large banks are directly exposed to the risk of insurance price increases or coverage withdrawal. Specifically, with the recent increase in acute climate-related physical risk comes the specter of home insurance price increases or possible denial of coverage in certain areas. For example, AIG recently announced plans to leave the California market due to climate risks. The most recent NOAA data shows that the U.S. has experienced 20 separate billion dollar weather and climate disasters in 2021. We believe that the bank market’s reliance on the availability of home insurance for its residential mortgage portfolio in particular could lead to a climate-related gap in risk monitoring. As such, we recommend that banks study the potential impact of residential property insurance price increases or coverage withdrawal on the value, default rate, loss given default, and financing cost of residential mortgage portfolio holdings. We ask the OCC to consider including this risk in “Management of Risk Areas, Legal/Compliance Risk”. There is also risk for other portions of the banks’ portfolios. With regards to the use of carbon offset credits (or other similar carbon trading schemes) as a risk mitigation strategy, Atmos recommends that the primary focus of banks should be on “absolute GHG reductions” through client engagement and portfolio allocation as opposed to “net GHG reductions” via financial engineering. Any such GHG offset strategies should be used sparingly and only as a last resort. Outside of insurance and offsets, banks’ relationships with their clients must be at the heart of any strategy for climate risk mitigation. Arguments that large banks “bank the entire economy” and as a result have no pathway to reduce their climate risk miss the critical role of client engagement and transition, and seek to ignore the banking industry’s willing participation in carbon-intensive practices to date. Business within a sector can be shifted towards companies with a higher share of sustainable assets and/or robust transition plans. The recently released Page 8 of 14
2030 plans from a few of the largest banks take initial steps with some of their client sectors. While further actions are needed, these are good initial steps. The availability of “investable opportunities” is an important factor in how easy it is to mitigate risk through sustainable finance. The current structure of the economy will mean that most banks, particularly the largest ones, will have a “long” exposure to the business-as-usual case and a “short” exposure to the transition scenario. However, proactive banks may be able to capture enough sustainable opportunities to adjust this balance in a way that manages their overall transition risk. 8. What, if any, climate-related financial products or services–for example, “green bonds,” derivatives, dedicated investment funds, or other instruments that take climate-related considerations into account–do banks offer to clients and customers? What risks, if any, do these products or services pose? Based on our interactions, many of the largest banks currently offer their borrowers a variety of “green” products, such as sustainability-linked loans, derivatives with embedded sustainability KPIs, etc. While we encourage banks to support their client’s climate risk management and sustainability efforts, banks should pay attention to the potential unique reputational risks these products entail, such as the risk of “greenwashing” by the bank and/or the borrower. Greenwashing is the process of knowingly or unknowingly conveying a false impression as to how sustainable or environmentally sound a product or service actually is. It can occur when the benefits conferred by the product or service are not material to the bank or borrower, or relevant to the borrower’s primary business activity. It is our opinion that the vast majority of existing products are “green” in name only. Similar to the SEC’s current initiatives to proactively identify ESG-related misconduct (SEC Division of Enforcement Climate and ESG Task Force), we encourage the OCC to include a requirement that bank compliance frameworks are updated to include greenwashing surveillance. As such, we ask the OCC to consider including this risk in “Management of Risk Areas, Other Nonfinancial Risk”. New companies and products, including Atmos Financial, are beginning to emerge to help banks with the transition. This emerging sector represents a significant economic opportunity for US-based solutions with global implications. Page 9 of 14
9. How do banks currently consider the impacts of climate-related financial risk mitigation strategies and financial products on households and communities, specifically LMI and other disadvantaged communities? The communities most affected by climate change will likely be those that historically represent LMI and other disadvantaged communities. Therefore it is imperative that banks incorporate this risk element when considering climate-related financial risk strategies. It would not, however, be an acceptable outcome for banks to retract accessibility to banking services and products from groups of disadvantaged communities based on risks from their geographic footprint. The OCC can and undoubtedly should play a pivotal role in assessing the legal and compliance impacts of a banks' strategic climate-related exit from certain geographies or community engagement against the legal and compliance requirements of the Fair Lending Act, National Flood Insurance Act and the Flood Disaster Protection Act. There are various strategies that could be incorporated by the OCC and/or legislative bodies to ensure the continued accessibility of financial products supporting disadvantageous communities. For banks to credibly assess the impacts of climate-related financial risk mitigation strategies and financial products on households and communities, specifically LMI and other disadvantaged communities, Atmos sides with other industry thought leaders and recommends that banks commit to principles of diversity, equity and inclusion and that bank board members and senior management are selected from a diverse and inclusive pool of candidates drawn from the communities that the financial institutions serve. Incorporating the principles of a just and inclusive economy is foundational to any effective climate risk management regime. We appreciate the OCC’s decision to withdraw the CRA requirements established by the prior administration. We encourage banks to build on their current efforts to include diverse voices into various levels of decision-making. It is important to have individuals representing different life experiences to advise on key financial decisions. Data, Disclosures, and Reporting 10. What, if any, specific climate-related data, metrics, tools, and models from borrowers and other counterparties do banks need to identify, measure, monitor, and control their own climate-related financial risks? How do banks currently obtain this information? Page 10 of 14
What gaps and other concerns are there with respect to these data, metrics, tools, or models? We recommend that banks obtain the following data in support of effective climate risk management: ● Scope 1, 2 and 3 GHG emissions data from borrowers, ● Information on planned capital expenditures and their likely impact on company emissions, as well as transition plans (if available), ● Geolocational information of all critical borrower infrastructure, ● Borrower climate disclosures prepared using the TCFD framework (banks should encourage borrowers to disclose this information using the TCFD framework to ensure that climate-relevant data is comparable across industries and geographies), ● Likely exposure to financial risks generated from necessary changes to end consumers in highly impacted areas. ● Detailed climate related assessments of collateral including but not limited to projections of the useful life of the asset. To minimize compliance costs, banks should also be encouraged and incentivized by the OCC to actively contribute to the development and sharing of climate-relevant borrower data, as appropriate. Banks should also be encouraged to use a common set of standards, such as the PCAF framework, for measuring their Scope 3 emissions associated with client activities. Without a standardized framework, and conforming that framework to international standards whenever possible, it may be difficult to accurately assess banks’ risk and the effectiveness of their mitigation strategies. However, under no circumstances should banks be allowed to let any perceived difficulty in standardizing assessment protocols preclude inclusion of Scope 3 emissions in their assessments. As banks compute the inventory of GHG emissions associated with their loan portfolio under a PCAF or other framework, banks may indicate the lack of investable opportunities puts undue burden on their shareholders. We do not think this is a valid argument. There is no shortage of opportunities, and scientific evidence has suggested as much as $100T needs to be invested in the clean economy over the next 20-30 years. 11. How could existing regulatory reporting requirements be augmented to better capture banks’ exposure to climate-related financial risks? Page 11 of 14
Atmos sides with other industry thought leaders and recommends that existing regulatory reporting requirements for banks be expanded to require the use of the TCFD framework to ensure that public disclosure of climate relevant information is comparable across banks of varying asset size, location, and business model. Additionally, as part of identifying and quantifying climate-related financial risks, Atmos believes that large banks in particular should establish and disclose net zero plans which describe in detail how they plan to decarbonize their business activities and achieve net zero emissions by no later than 2050. Furthermore, large banks should set interim decarbonization goals (for example, 2030 goals) and provide regular updates towards achieving them, to ensure a financially-stable glidepath that ensures we meet the UN’s 1.5 degree target. Finally, all interim goals and 2050 net zero commitments should incorporate the latest science, use credible climate scenarios and disclose decarbonization progress on a sector by sector basis. Detailed disclosure of net zero and interim goals will ensure that large banks sufficiently participate in the decarbonization of the economy just as they disproportionately benefited from the industrial activities leading to the climate crisis. We encourage the OCC to consider augmenting existing regulatory reporting requirements to include this additional risk-mitigating disclosure. Scenario Analysis 12. Scenario analysis is an important component of climate risk management that requires assumptions about plausible future states of the world. How do banks use climate scenario models, analysis, or tools and what challenges do they face? Broadly, real estate lending decisions have taken into account likelihood of natural disasters based on historical probability analyses. This form of historical analysis is no longer able to project the future potential for risk. Therefore, science-based scenario analysis is a critical component of measuring climate-related financial risks inherent to a bank’s lending portfolio. The primary challenge confronting most banks will be a lack of prescriptive guidance on which modeling to use, and the incorporation of such modeling. It is unlikely that most banks will be able to make an appropriate science-based determination of that risk. Specialty companies Page 12 of 14
have started to emerge to aid banks in making these determinations. It is our opinion that such practices and assessment specialties will be adopted by audit and assurance firms, speciality companies and insurance companies. This is an appropriate division of power to maintain objectivity, though it requires significant regulation and guidance of such firms providing those services as well as prescriptive guidance on how such information is used to prevent further abuse of disadvantaged communities. The use of climate-risk scenario analysis and/or climate-risk stress testing for regional and community banks can be characterized as being in its infancy. The main challenges they face in advancing their climate scenario analysis and stress testing programs are both technical and operational in nature: ● Some regional and community banks do not yet consider climate to be a material risk factor, and so are not engaging their borrowers in obtaining climate-relevant data, ● When client engagement does occur, borrowers are unable or unwilling to provide climate data (for example, GHG emissions), ● In all cases, regional and community banks are unsure of which climate scenarios are most relevant for their business model, ● Furthermore, they are often waiting for regulatory guidance before investing resources in the design of climate-risk scenario analysis and/or climate-risk stress capabilities. 13. What factors are most salient for the OCC to consider when designing and executing scenario analysis exercises? When designing and executing scenario analysis, at a micro-level, we believe that the scientific rigor and transparency of the scenarios are paramount. As such, banks should ensure that their scenarios: ● Are science-based and aligned with the most current climate change science, ● For transition risk, the scenarios should consider both an “orderly” and “disorderly” transition, ● For physical risk, the scenarios should contain at least one "worst case" scenario, ● Assumptions regarding both demand and prices for commodities (such as oil) should be transparent and clearly stated, and ● Scenarios should be aligned with current best practices (i.e., IEA and NGFS scenarios). From a macro-standpoint, the U.S. regulatory regime has proven itself to be robust and flexible enough to meet the challenge of many recent perils. For example, due to the effectiveness of Page 13 of 14
periodic scenario analysis testing and monitoring of capital requirements, regulators have been able to successfully navigate new threats to bank safety and soundness such as cybersecurity and the coronavirus pandemic. We believe that thorough and well executed risk management procedures that include climate-related financial risks can offer similar safeguards for financial stability. Thus when considering which macro factors are most salient to designing and executing climate scenario analysis exercises we recommend that first and foremost the OCC continue to act with a sense of urgency around this existential and systemic threat. Second, as climate change risk permeates all aspects of the capital markets and poses grave threats to banks of all sizes and business models, we recommend that these scenario analysis exercises should be adopted by all U.S. banks irrespective of asset size, location, or business model. Third, the OCC will need to ensure that banks have access to educational resources in support of bank innovation regarding climate scenarios, models and data. Finally, we believe that climate scenario analysis exercises should eventually evolve into a formalized climate stress testing regime which informs regulatory capital adequacy metrics. Without climate stress testing, we believe that banks are at risk of running a higher quantum of enterprise risk than they are aware of, posing a danger to the safety and soundness of our financial system. Once again, we congratulate the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for its fine work in developing these Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management for Large Banks. Your leadership on this critical issue is deeply valued. We would be pleased to discuss any questions you may have on our feedback. Sincerely, Peter Hellwig, Co-Founder Atmos Financial, PBC Page 14 of 14
summary: Atmos Financial, a financial technology banking services provider, submitted comments on the OCC's Principles for Climate-Related Financial Risk Management for Large Banks. Atmos supports extending these principles to all U.S. banks, regardless of size, due to the pervasive threat of climate change. They highlight the increasing frequency and severity of climate-related disasters and their financial impacts, urging the OCC to enforce mandatory climate risk management practices. Atmos suggests a staggered implementation timeline for smaller banks and emphasizes the need for detailed guidance on self-assessment of climate risks. They advocate for aligning U.S. regulations with international standards and stress the importance of incorporating long-term climate risks into financial assessments. Atmos also calls for transparency in climate-related financial products to avoid greenwashing and recommends that banks consider the impacts of climate risk strategies on disadvantaged communities. They propose using the TCFD framework for regulatory reporting and emphasize the need for science-based scenario analysis. Atmos concludes by urging the OCC to act urgently and develop a formal climate stress testing regime to ensure financial stability.

comment:
Thank you, Comptroller Hsu, for taking up the issue of climate change and banks. 
We need actions, not empty promises.  The Banking industry is NOT concerned with the climate crisis, but only PROFITS.  We are killing and exploiting our planet and leaving a dismal future for the next generations.  This is not our only option, but due to greed and selfishness and lack of ethical standards, this is where we are. ENOUGH!!
This can all be different if we actually, act boldly, regulate them to standards to save our planet, ENFORCE THEM. WE OWE IT TO THE FUTURE GENERATIONS!!!  My heart breaks how greedy and selfish humanity has become and the lack of solidarity.  PATHETIC!
Even as banks publicly claim to be taking climate change seriously and phasing out financing for greenhouse gas emissions, they are investing billions into companies that produce fossil fuels. Banks' continued investments in fossil fuels are driving climate change – a crisis that puts our financial system, people of color and low-income communities, and our planet at risk. 
Regulators must not let financial institutions gamble with our future. We need you to push banks to take the urgent steps necessary to address the dangers they face from climate change, as stop their short-term business decisions from endangering our economy and communities.
I support the proposed guidance’s recommendations to banks that they:
Incorporate climate-related risk management into every level of business;
Plan for climate change over a long time horizon, and update models as additional data becomes available;
Develop clear definitions of possible climate-related risk exposures, and metrics for setting limits; 
And make sure that their internal strategies are consistent with their public-facing climate commitments.
The OCC must ensure that banks’ actions match their commitments to zeroing out their net carbon emissions. Banks’ management of climate risk should be factored into their supervisory ratings, too.
It is in the best interest of both the public and banks themselves to act now to minimize climate risk. The OCC must use the full extent of its authority to issue strong final guidance to banks on climate risk, continue to protect against unsafe and unsound bank practices, and require remedies from banks where appropriate.
summary: The commenter expresses strong support for Comptroller Hsu's focus on climate change and banks, emphasizing the need for concrete actions rather than empty promises. They criticize the banking industry's prioritization of profits over environmental concerns, accusing banks of contributing to climate change by investing in fossil fuels. The commenter urges regulators to enforce strict standards to protect future generations and prevent financial institutions from making short-term decisions that harm the economy and communities. They support the proposed guidance for banks to integrate climate risk management, plan for long-term climate change, and ensure internal strategies align with public climate commitments. The commenter calls for the OCC to use its authority to enforce strong guidance and require banks to address climate risks effectively.

comment: Mr. James P. Sheesley, Assistant Executive Secretary   Attention: Comments--RIN 3064-ZA32   Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation   550 17th Street NW   Washington, DC 20429      Dear Mr. Sheesley:    FDIC Requested Comment Climate-Related Financial Risk I am Rick Holder, former President and CEO  and presently Chairman and CFO of Cattlemens Bank. We are an AG bank in Oklahoma and Texas. We  have total assets of 450 million and a large ag and agribusiness loan portfolio. My concern is this rule will  eventually affect ag banks of my size. Our bank was established in 1910. We have dealt with adverse  climate affects our whole existence. Just in my forty-year career we have experienced five severe  droughts, several floods and extreme heat. All of these events have had effects on the profitability of  our bank. The Ag banks that are still in business could teach the class on "climate related financial risk"  mitigation. We don't need another rule to follow while we do our job of mitigating weather risk to our  bank. I would like to thank the FDIC for allowing community banks to comment on this new rule and not  applying it to community banks.   Sincerely,    Rick Holder   Chairman/CFO Cattlemens Bank
summary: Rick Holder, Chairman and CFO of Cattlemens Bank, expresses concerns about a proposed FDIC rule on climate-related financial risk, fearing it may eventually impact agricultural banks like his, which operates in Oklahoma and Texas with $450 million in assets. Holder highlights the bank's long history of managing climate impacts, citing experiences with severe droughts, floods, and extreme heat over his 40-year career. He argues that agricultural banks have developed effective strategies for mitigating climate-related financial risks and do not require additional regulatory rules. Holder appreciates the FDIC's decision to allow community banks to comment on the rule and for not applying it to them.

The comment criticizes big banks for financing the fossil fuel industry, contributing to climate change and related economic damages. It argues that financial regulators must address the moral hazards of banks prioritizing short-term gains over long-term public harm. The commenter supports proposed guidance urging banks to integrate climate risk management at all business levels, plan for long-term climate impacts, define risk exposures, and align internal strategies with public climate commitments. They emphasize that the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) should ensure banks' actions align with their net-zero carbon commitments and incorporate climate risk management into supervisory ratings. The commenter calls for the OCC to impose significant penalties for non-compliance and to issue strong guidance to mitigate climate risks, protecting both the public and banks.

Developing Climate Risk Assessment Regulations or Climate Risk Regulatory Guidance is a daunting task for many reasons. To begin with, Climate Risk needs to be clearly defined. Many articles and studies on Climate Risk focus on the future and speculate on widely differing scenarios about how Climate Change will affect Climate Risk. In my opinion, commingling Climate Risk with Climate Change is a mistake at this time. The extent and effects of Climate Change remain the subject of a continuing debate about both the degree of climate change, the rate of climate change, and the effects of Climate Change.
When developing possible guidance and potential regulations pertaining to Climate Risk why not start with a “first generation” basic Climate Risk model and then build upon that model with time and experience?
What do I mean by a basic Climate Risk model? What I suggest is that the first generation of Climate Risk Assessments should be based on Climate Risk as it exists today without the controversy surrounding Climate Change speculation. 
This approach has many advantages. First, as with any new regulation, the first generation of Climate Risk Assessment Models will be controversial. Adopting a Climate Risk Model that is based on current-day conditions reduces the speculation and controversy involved when incorporating Climate Change considerations.
Second, there already exists data that measure climate exposure for many natural hazards, including flooding, hurricanes, earthquakes, drought, severe cold, and more than a dozen other climate-related phenomena that are currently a real and immediate threat to banks and the communities they serve.
Third, by focusing on imminent climate-related threats, climate risk assessments are not only likely to be more accurate but are more likely to attract more support because it’s easier to perceive and appreciate a threat that currently exists and could happen any day, rather than a threat that may be decades away.
How quickly could such a Climate Risk Assessment Model be developed? The answer is such a model already is available. Using data generated by at least 8 federal agencies GeoDataVision has adapted that data for banking purposes so that risk ratings in that data can be assigned to any bank asset, facility, loan or collateral location, etc. If anyone from the OCC is interested in reviewing the maps and risk ratings within the model, I would be pleased to provide a demonstration. We have written an article for publication regarding the model and are awaiting the approval process. As soon as that article is published (expected the first week of February) we will provide a copy to the OCC. Len Suzio
summary: The comment addresses the challenges of developing Climate Risk Assessment Regulations, emphasizing the need to clearly define Climate Risk separately from Climate Change. The author argues against conflating Climate Risk with Climate Change due to ongoing debates about the latter's extent and effects. They propose starting with a "first generation" Climate Risk model based on current conditions, which would reduce speculation and controversy. This model would utilize existing data on natural hazards like flooding and hurricanes, making assessments more accurate and garnering more support by focusing on immediate threats. The author claims such a model already exists, adapted by GeoDataVision using federal data for banking purposes, and offers to demonstrate it to the OCC. An article on the model is pending publication.

comment: Mr. James P. Sheesley, Assistant Executive Secretary   Attention: Comments--RIN 3064-ZA32   Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation   550 17th Street NW   Washington, DC 20429      Dear Mr. Sheesley:      I am submitting this letter in response to the FDIC request for comment on the Statement of principles  laid out in FIL-13-2022. This statement addresses climate related risks and risk management implication  for Large Financial Institutions. I am the President of a one billion dollar community bank in Marion  Iowa. We have been serving our community for over 95 years with a strong focus on agricultural and  loans within our community to both individuals and businesses. I would like to acknowledge the  consideration for limiting this proposal to institution with total assets over $100 billion. While this does  restrict the initial proposal I have significant concerns that these standards may be applied to  community banks and significantly impact our ability to provide products and services to our customers.  The increased assessment would lead to higher costs to customers, restrictions in product offerings to  customers and significant negative impact to the economy of the area. We as a bank have an in depth  knowledge and understanding of the risks both to our customers and our portfolio as do most  community banks. This proposal regardless of the level of application will have a negative impact on our  community and others. Thanks for allowing the opportunity to comment on the proposed framework  and I would encourage continued outreach and communication with banks at all levels but particularly  community banks as these proposals evolve.    Regards,   Gene Neighbor   President and CEO, Farmers State Bank    Farmers State Bank   1240 8th Ave  Marion, IA 52317
summary: Gene Neighbor, President and CEO of Farmers State Bank, responds to the FDIC's request for comments on climate-related risk management principles for large financial institutions. Neighbor appreciates the proposal's current limitation to institutions with assets over $100 billion but expresses concern that these standards might eventually apply to community banks like his. He argues that such application could increase costs for customers, limit product offerings, and negatively impact local economies. Neighbor emphasizes that community banks possess a deep understanding of their risks and customer needs. He urges the FDIC to maintain open communication with banks of all sizes, especially community banks, as the proposals develop.

Thank you, Comptroller Hsu, for taking up the issue of climate change and banks. 
Even as banks publicly claim to be taking climate change seriously and phasing out financing for greenhouse gas emissions, they are investing billions into companies that produce fossil fuels. Banks' continued investments in fossil fuels are driving climate change – a crisis that puts our financial system, people of color and low-income communities, and our planet at risk. 
Regulators must not let financial institutions gamble with our future. We need you to push banks to take the urgent steps necessary to address the dangers they face from climate change, as stop their short-term business decisions from endangering our economy and communities.
I support the proposed guidance’s recommendations to banks that they:
Incorporate climate-related risk management into every level of business;
Plan for climate change over a long time horizon, and update models as additional data becomes available;
Develop clear definitions of possible climate-related risk exposures, and metrics for setting limits; 
And make sure that their internal strategies are consistent with their public-facing climate commitments.
The OCC must ensure that banks’ actions match their commitments to zeroing out their net carbon emissions. Banks’ management of climate risk should be factored into their supervisory ratings, too.
It is in the best interest of both the public and banks themselves to act now to minimize climate risk. The OCC must use the full extent of its authority to issue strong final guidance to banks on climate risk, continue to protect against unsafe and unsound bank practices, and require remedies from banks where appropriate.+
Failure on the part of banks to act now will prove far more costly in the future — if indeed we have a future, given the exponential increase in damaging evidence of climate change, climate shock, global warming caused by continuing to rely on fossil fuels. I have divested myself from holdings having anything to do with fossil fuels, really a necessity for individuals as well as over-large banks out for immediate profit to the detriment of our country's citizens and the wider world.
summary: The comment addresses Comptroller Hsu, expressing concern over banks' investments in fossil fuels despite their public commitments to combat climate change. It argues that these investments exacerbate climate change, posing risks to the financial system, marginalized communities, and the planet. The commenter supports proposed guidance urging banks to integrate climate risk management into their operations, plan for long-term climate impacts, and align internal strategies with public climate commitments. They advocate for the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) to enforce strong guidance and ensure banks' actions align with their zero-carbon commitments. The comment emphasizes the urgency of addressing climate risks to prevent future costs and highlights personal divestment from fossil fuels as a necessary step for individuals and institutions.
